title: Problem Statement
content: Erdos Problem #268 asks about the topology of harmonic subseries points. Given an infinite set A with convergent harmonic sum, we can form a d-dimensional point by taking shifted sums. The question is whether the set X of all such points has nonempty interior (contains an open ball).

title: Answer: YES
content: The answer is YES for all dimensions d >= 1. Erdos-Straus proved d=2 first. Kovac (2024) proved d=3 with an explicit open ball construction. Kovac-Tao (2024) proved all dimensions using Ahmes series techniques.

title: Convergent Harmonic Subseries
content: A set A has a convergent harmonic subseries if the sum of 1/n over n in A is finite. This requires A to be 'thin'--the harmonic series diverges, so A cannot contain too many elements. Examples include squares {1, 4, 9, ...} and powers of 2 {1, 2, 4, 8, ...}.

title: Shifted Harmonic Sum
content: The shifted harmonic sum is the sum of 1/(n+k) over n in A. For k=0 we get the ordinary harmonic subseries. For k=1, we sum 1/(n+1). Each coordinate of our point uses a different shift k = 0, 1, ..., d-1.

title: Finite Sets Converge
content: Any finite set A trivially has a convergent harmonic subseries--a finite sum is always finite. The interesting case is infinite sets where the terms go to zero fast enough for convergence.

title: Shifted Series Also Converge
content: If sum 1/n converges over A, then sum 1/(n+k) also converges for any fixed k. This is because 1/(n+k) <= 1/n for large n, and we can apply the comparison test. This ensures all coordinates of our point are well-defined.

title: The Harmonic Point
content: Given a set A and dimension d, we form the harmonic point as a function from Fin d to R. The i-th coordinate is the shifted sum with shift i. So the point is (sum 1/n, sum 1/(n+1), ..., sum 1/(n+d-1)).

title: The Point Set X
content: The set X (harmonicPointSet d) consists of all harmonic points as A ranges over infinite sets with convergent harmonic subseries. This is the main object of study--we ask whether X has nonempty interior.

title: Main Result (Axiomatized)
content: The main theorem states that the interior of X is nonempty for all dimensions d. This is axiomatized because the proof by Kovac and Kovac-Tao involves sophisticated analysis techniques not yet in Mathlib. The axiom captures the established mathematical result.

title: Contains Open Ball
content: We prove that 'nonempty interior' is equivalent to containing an open ball. Given the axiom that interior is nonempty, we extract a point x in the interior, then use the metric space definition of interior to find a ball around x contained in X.

title: Erdos-Straus (d=2)
content: Erdos and Straus proved the 2-dimensional case. The set of points (sum 1/n, sum 1/(n+1)) has nonempty interior in R^2. This was the first breakthrough on the problem, establishing that the phenomenon does occur.

title: Kovac's Theorem (d=3)
content: Kovac (2024) proved the 3-dimensional case with an explicit construction. He found a specific open ball (center and radius) that lies inside X. This constructive approach gives concrete geometric information about the set.

title: Explicit Ball Construction
content: We define placeholder values for Kovac's ball center and radius. In the actual proof, Kovac computed specific numerical values showing an explicit ball lies in X. The axiom kovac_explicit_ball captures this result.

title: Kovac-Tao General Result
content: Kovac and Tao (2024) proved the result for all dimensions d >= 1. Their proof uses techniques from Ahmes series (Egyptian fractions), connecting this topological question to classical number theory.

title: Ahmes Series Connection
content: An Ahmes series is another name for an Egyptian fraction representation--expressing a number as a sum of distinct unit fractions 1/n. Kovac-Tao linked the harmonic subseries problem to questions about which numbers can be represented as Ahmes series.

title: X is Non-empty
content: The set X is non-empty because we can always find infinite sets with convergent harmonic subseries. For instance, the set of squares {1, 4, 9, 16, ...} works since sum 1/n^2 = pi^2/6 is finite.

title: X is Path-Connected
content: The set X is path-connected. Intuitively, we can continuously deform one infinite set A into another B while maintaining convergence, tracing a path in X. This shows X has nice topological properties beyond just having interior.

title: Coordinates Decrease
content: The coordinates of a harmonic point are decreasing: the sum 1/n is larger than sum 1/(n+1), which is larger than sum 1/(n+2), etc. This is because 1/n > 1/(n+k) for k > 0, and the comparison holds term by term.

title: All Coordinates Positive
content: All coordinates of a harmonic point are positive (for non-empty A). This is because each term 1/(n+k) is positive, and we're summing positive terms. So X lies entirely in the positive orthant of R^d.

title: Projection Preserves X
content: Projecting from higher to lower dimensions maps X to X. If we project a point in X_d (d-dimensional) to its first d' coordinates, we get a point in X_{d'}. This is because the same set A generates both points.

title: Squares Example
content: The set of perfect squares {1, 4, 9, 16, ...} has a convergent harmonic subseries since sum 1/n^2 = pi^2/6. This gives a specific point in X whose first coordinate is pi^2/6 approximately 1.645.

title: Powers of 2 Example
content: The set of powers of 2 {1, 2, 4, 8, ...} has a convergent harmonic subseries since sum 1/2^k = 1 (geometric series). The first coordinate of this point is exactly 1. This gives another explicit point in X.
